lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can write sentences (e.g., “It’s five ten.”) clearly and accurately in the correct space.
supportStrategies: (Writing) Write model: “It’s five ten.” Students copy, then write 2 more times from flashcards or clocks they choose.
stretchStrategies: Students complete a mingle survey with the whole class: “What time do you...?” They write down classmates’ answers, then analyse who wakes up earliest/late, has lunch earliest, etc., and share 2–3 interesting findings aloud.

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can listen to spoken descriptions and select the correct time.
supportStrategies: (Listening) Say: “It’s one fifteen.” Students match to the correct clock. Then say: “Who gets up at 7:00?” Students identify the character from SB.
stretchStrategies: Students complete a mingle survey with the whole class: “What time do you...?” They write down classmates’ answers, then analyse who wakes up earliest/late, has lunch earliest, etc., and share 2–3 interesting findings aloud.

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can work together politely and take turns to complete a mingle activity.
supportStrategies: (4Cs – Mingle) Give each student a time card and daily routine. They walk around asking: “What time do you ___?” and respond, recording 3 classmates’ answers.
stretchStrategies: Students complete a mingle survey with the whole class: “What time do you...?” They write down classmates’ answers, then analyse who wakes up earliest/late, has lunch earliest, etc., and share 2–3 interesting findings aloud.

items: Consonant clusters do not exist in Vietnamese words, so they need special attention. Remember that clusters don't come only at the beginning of words – end clusters can be even harder (dogs, task, crisp, crisps, snacks)
A wide variety of syllabus hobbies may be less popular or available to some Vietnamese students (practising the flute; seeing famous paintings), although many overlap

In Vietnamese, final consonants are 'held in' – you don't actually hear them released. But in English, the final consonant of cat, top, rock, and so on are released with a puff of air. Make sure you are aware of this difference.
Do not exist in standard Vietnamese, written or spoken. The hardest part for YLs is learning to pronounce them naturally: there's a dog rather than there is a dog.
